Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about your pain. I had the scar tissue problem but it did not involve the pain you describe. My stream was weak from the start and just got weaker. Ultimately I was flexing stomach muscles to help the stream. What ends up happening is your bladder does not empty completely and you start having to go very frequently (every hour). I waited too long. Good your checking with your doc now.

Posts.Title: Bladder Spasm?

Posts.Content: Bloating for me was a problem for the first few weeks. I found that when I walked for an hour straight bloating finally went away. I could do 30 to 40 minutes straight the day after surgery, but at home I started with 20 minute workouts and did three per day. Before surgery I regularly walked for an hour each day and included 10 minutes of running.

Posts.Title: Choosing Surgeon in NYC

Posts.Content: Saturation biopsies don't hurt as long as you are knocked out, as was the case for my two saturation biopsies. The second one was guided by MRI to focus on a suspicious area. It proved nothing there. Check my signature. Lots of biopsie needles, three bad cores with very small Gleason 6 cells. But even with all of this, I was still upgraded to Gleason 7. MRIs alone didn't find cancer. Saturation biopsies didn't find Gleason 7 cells, but they were there.

Posts.Title: Should I suggest a saturation biopsy...and how to prepare for the results

Posts.Content: An MRI before biopsy can also serve as a baseline against which future MRIs can be compared. An MRI WILL NOT take the place of a biopsy. Your doctors have a number of tools to detect and gauge the severity of PCa including, PCA3, ultrasounds, PSA FREE, PSA and genetic testing. Until something better comes along, the biopsy is the best gauge.

Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: For me passing gas had nothing to do with the bloated belly. I was passing gas in the hospital the night of my surgery. The bloating lasted three weeks, long after bowel movements, real food, and lots of farts. While I was capable of walking for an hour at a time, I broke my walking up into 20 minute periods. I think that was a mistake. When I finally started walking for an hour straight, the bloating subsided. My solution would be walk for an hour as long as you are physically up to it. Here's hoping you feel better soon.

Posts.Title: My kingdom for a fart !!

Posts.Content: You may want to take a look at this discussion on strictures: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ight=stricture About 4 weeks after my surgery I had another catheter because of a stricture. I was then scheduled for an urethrotomy nine day later. In this procedure the doctor uses a scope with a cutting instrument to clean out the scar tissue. I then had to remain on the fat catheter for another week though. When the catheter came out my flow was great. I think the expression is, Like a race horse great. The danger though was that the scar tissue could come back. To ensure it didn't, my doctor had me self- catheterize. Sounds worse than it was. I did this twice a day for two weeks. Then for the next two weeks it was once each day. For the next 10 weeks it was once per week. So after four months of this treatment, no more stricture! Now my case may be very different than yours, but I would also suggest that you get a second opinion.

Posts.Title: Urethral Stricture

Posts.Content: My doc used two catheters! The typical one that comes out easily. No pain, just a strange sensation. In my case this catheter was closed off and never used, but was there if needed. The working catheter, Supra Pubic Catheter, was inserted through the lower belly directly into the bladder. It helped to properly position the bladder after surgery and is believed to aid continence. The nurse cut the stitch holding it in -- no pain. But when she pulled it out it hurt like hell. Luckily the pain only lasted for two seconds.

Posts.Content: Check out these two threads: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads/47101-Probability https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...-Cancer-and-AS There are references to one or two key studies. Bottom line: intraductal is a rare, more aggressive cancer. Finding it on a biopsie is rare too. Sending your biopsie slides for a second opinion would be a good idea as intraductal is sometimes misdiagnosed. Treatment should be sought soon. In my case, my surgeon followed me closely even at 3 years post surgery every six months. Now on an annual follow-up. Surgery seems to have done the trick. Four and 1/2 years and PSA is <.006

Posts.Title: Now I'm even more nervous

Posts.Content: While you need to drink a lot during the day (my doc had a daily total oz goal for the day during the first few weeks), you should stop in the evening unless you want to get up during the night. I would stop drinking by 7pm. My goal was to go through the night without getting up. Get Depends, male diapers and put a pad in it. It should keep you from wetting the bed. You can sleep on a towel for extra protection. You'll see progress over time, especially if you keep a daily chart. Keep track of when you get up during the night, pad usage, etc. Before you know it you will be charting erections, penetration, and your spouse/partners orgasms.

Posts.Title: Kegels for how long?

Posts.Content: My doc prescribed 20 mg of Cialis three days each week (Tues. Th. & Sat) with 100 mg of Viagra twice each week (Tuesday & Sat). After 6 months he suggested shots or MUSE. I opted for MUSE. Seemed like it would be easier to do. So I substituted MUSE for a Viagra once each week. About a month of this led to success. Able to have intercourse. With MUSE you insert a tiny pellet into the penis by using a small applicator. I took 2 Advils one hour before the MUSE because MUSE tends to cause discomfort. With the Advil it was bearable. About the 11 month mark I stopped the MUSE and changed to 5mg daily cialis and 100 mg Viagra before intercourse. At 14 months, just Viagra.

Posts.Title: Pls punch my card again!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." Though there is always the chance of finding a 3+4 or 4+3 in the post surgical pathology report, the information above may well allow many more men to be willing to go ahead with AS for several years. Zero in 14,000 is pretty impressive. Very true, but there is still a small chance of Recurrence with a PSA between 4 and 10 and clean margins after surgery. From Johns Hopkins: "Probability Following Radical Prostatectomy Probability of Biochemical Recurrence (detectable PSA level) at : 3 years after surgery: 2% (1-5) 5 years after surgery: 3% (1- 7 years after surgery: 4% (2-12) 10 years after surgery: 6% (2-15) All numbers represent predictive probabilities with a 95 percent confidence interval"

Posts.Title: Great Article about Gleason 6, New Gleason Groups

Posts.Content: A urinary stricture blocks urine flow. Your doctor will be able to test your urine flow by measuring the amount of urine and how long it takes to empty your bladder. Retaining urine, not emptying your bladder, can lead to serious complications. The doctor will be able to tell if you have a stricture. The stricture is scar tissue. If you have a stricture the treatment is to keep the passage open because they tend to build up again and block the flow. In my case I went back on a catheter for two weeks. When the catheter came out my flow was great. The danger though was that the scar tissue could come back. To ensure it didn't, my doctor had me self- catheterize. Sounds worse than it was. The catheter is a flexible 18 inch thin tube. You have to insert it until it enters the bladder. So after urinating I would insert the catheter. As long as only a few drops came out I knew I was emptying my bladder. I did this twice a day for two weeks. Then for the next two weeks it was once each day. For the next 10 weeks it was once per week. So after four months of this treatment, no more stricture!

Posts.Content: Time to get a new nurse! Pca3 measures a prostate cancer gene found in urine. BRCA2, a breast cancer gene thought to be related to prostate cancer is measured in a blood test. The typical cutoff is 35. Scores greater than 35 indicate an increased risk of PC.

Posts.Title: PCA3 question

Posts.Content: No ED issues before surgery. Only pre-surgery urinary symptom was minor dribbling at end of urination. Pathology showed PIN and acute and chronic inflammation BPH. Usually slept through the night; on occasion made one trip to pee. ED issues can take from 6 months to 2 years to improve. For a soon to be 67 year-old, I'm very fortunate. It was not until my seventh month that I was ready for intercourse. That was after a month of using MUSE once a week. My protocol was 20 mg of Cialis three days each week (Tues. Th. & Sat) with 100 mg of Viagra twice each week (Tuesday & Sat). After my 6 month visit, doc said try injections or MUSE. I opted for MUSE. Others here have talked about how helpful the shots are, but figured I would try MUSE first. So once a week for about a month I substituted MUSE for a Viagra. About a month of this led to success. With MUSE you insert a tiny pellet into the penis by using a small applicator. Having had to self-catheterize myself for what seemed like forever because of a rare urinary stricture, this did not seem bad at all. I took 2 Advils one hour before the MUSE because MUSE tends to cause discomfort. With the Advil it was bearable. Although as soon as I could, I stopped the MUSE and went back to Viagra. Best wishes for a speedy recovery.

Posts.Title: 1Year Post Robotic--Life is Good!

Posts.Content: PSA is undetectable. I can go 4, 5, or 6 hours without stoping in the rest room to pee and no leaking. Erections still improving. Stopped MUSE. Dropped down from 20 mg cialis to 5 mg + Viagra. This combination yields a strong erection. Hope to drop Viagra soon. Even Had sex laying down in bed. Right after surgery I never thought I would say it, but I feel normal and life is good!

Posts.Title: 1Year Post Robotic--Life is Good!

Posts.Content: Consistency of bowel movements will be affected by diet and fluid intake. After surgery you my be drinking more than you did pre-surgery, especially if you take to heart the fluid intake reccomendtions provided by your doctor. Thinking back to what it was like right after surgery, I recall feeling a little tender during bowel movements up to six months post surgery. Remember that the area your prostate used to occupy was torn apart to gain access to the prostate. Eventually all of that will go back to normal. For the first five months or so I would frequently be checking to see if I was leaking. You know, subtlety feeling my pants to see if they were wet. They never were, but let's face it our confidence has been severely challenged. These days I don't have the need to always be checking. It takes awhile to gain the confidence and ability to fart without leaking, but it will come. You are still early in your recuperation. I have had a pain in my bladder area in the middle of the night with the feeling that I have to pee. I would jump up and find that a few drops leaked out before getting to the toilet. This has happened less and less frequently. Maybe this has happened once in the last three months. All in all this is not much to deal with.

Posts.Content: My doc prescribed 20 mg of Cialis three days each week (Tues. Th. & Sat) with 100 mg of Viagra twice each week (Tuesday & Sat). After 6 months I substituted MUSE for a Viagra once each week. About a month of this led to success. With MUSE you insert a tiny pellet into the penis by using a small applicator. I took 2 Advils one hour before the MUSE because MUSE tends to cause discomfort. With the Advil it was bearable. About the 11 month mark I stopped the MUSE and changed to 5mg daily cialis and 100 mg Viagra before intercourse. At the 14 month mark just using 100 mg of Viagra before sex. Don't give up. Things get bigger, err better!

Posts.Content: Before deciding on a biopsy, top urologists today will evaluate not only the PSA level and it's trend over time, but also the PSA density and % free. Both of these can provide a probability that a biopsy will show cancer. Another test, PCA3, is also used to gauge the probability that a biopsy will confirm cancer. With low probabilities for these tests and indicators, your urologist may recommend that you wait on the biopsy.

Posts.Title: Cialis and Viagra ??

Posts.Content: My stream was weak from the first day of catheter removal and just got weaker. Ultimately I was flexing stomach muscles to help the stream. What ends up happening is your bladder does not empty completely and you start having to go very frequently (every hour). This can become a serious problem. Retaining urine is not a good thing. I waited too long about 5 or 6 weeks before I went in to get it checked. I had a urinary stricture. It blocks urine flow. They dont know why it occurred. It was not at the point where the urethra was sutured. Your doctor will be able to test your urine flow by measuring the amount of urine you produce and how long it takes to empty your bladder. If you are not emptying completely the doctor will be able to tell if you have a stricture. The stricture is scar tissue. If you have a stricture the treatment is to keep the passage open because the scar tissue tends to build up again and block the flow. When I went to the doctors office they easily saw I was not emptying completely. So the first line of treatment is to self-catheterize. The PA explained what to do. I was supposed to follow-up at home with the self-catheterization. So I tried to self-catheterize but could not get it in. The PA tried two more times - unsuccessful, bloody and painful. They rolled me into the procedure room and the doctor did a cystoscopy with numbing jell (put did not help enough). He used the thinnest wire and after a lot of poking, gradually worked up to a wider tube so that ultimately he could look inside and finally inserted a fat catheter. Very painful despite numbing jell. I was scheduled for an urethrotomy nine day later. In this procedure the doctor uses a scope with a cutting instrument to clean out the scar tissue. Since this was more than 30 days after my surgery I had to have another preop check. Blood, heart, chest, etc. When it came time for the urine test I pulled up my large catheter bag opened it up and poured out a rather district red sample. This was a really long bad day. Nine days later when it was time for the next procedure I was prepped knocked out and awoke in the recovery room to learn that much to everyones surprise there was no more scar tissue to remove. Seems all the earlier suffering and poking opened everything up. I did have to remain on the fat catheter for another week though. When the catheter came out my flow was great. I think the expression is, Like a race horse great. The danger though was that the scar tissue could come back. To ensure it didn't, my doctor had me self- catheterize. Sounds worse than it was. The catheter is a flexible 18 inch thin tube. You have to insert it until it enters the bladder. So after urinating I would insert the catheter. As long as only a few drops came out I knew I was emptying my bladder. I did this twice a day for two weeks. Then for the next two weeks it was once each day. For the next 10 weeks it was once per week. So after four months of this treatment, no more stricture! The moral of this story is if you have a weak stream when the catheter comes out you should be back in the doctors office getting it checked. Waiting a couple of days to see if it improves is one thing. Waiting weeks is not a good idea.

Posts.Content: Have you had other tests like PCA3? You might consider a saturation biopsy. With about 50 samples taken you have a better chance of finding cancer than with a typical 12 core biopsy. I was on Active Surveillance for almost 2 years with 2 saturation biopsies. Very little cancer was found with the biopsies. But my last PCA3 score was very high. My doctor advised treatment. My post-op pathology was upgraded to Gleason 7. It turns out my Gleason 7 was a more aggressive cancer (Intraductal). If your rising PSA score has been consistently going up and not just fluctuating, I would recommend you look closely at a Saturation biopsy.

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsies but rapidly rising PSA

Posts.Content: Over almost two years, I had two, 50 core biopsies that showed small Gleason 6 cancer in just three cores. Post-op it turned out to be Gleason 7 (3+4). Ill never know what a 12 core biopsy would have revealed, but I am glad I did the saturation biopsies and fortunate to have done the surgery when I did. My cancer was present in the nerves of the prostate. It is thought that traveling along the nerves is one of the ways it can spread. My doc also monitored PCA3. In the end, my decision to do robotic surgery was influenced in part by my high PCA3 numbers. A urine test measures the PCA3 gene which is prostate cancer specific. It is not influenced by the size of the prostate. During the DRE, the prostate is massaged (milked). Results depend upon the experience of the person doing the exam. So if you dont have an infection and you are thinking about Active Surveillance I would suggest you consider a plan that includes saturation biopsies, regular PSA tests, DREs, MRIs, Ultrasounds, and PCA3 tests. They are all different ways to gauge if cancer is present and how significant it can be. None of them is perfect. No one can predict the future with the degree of certainty we would like. Delaying treatment too long precludes some treatments and runs the risk that the disease will spread. Knowing when to stop AS and begin treatment can be tricky when the biopsy shows a small cancer and the conventional wisdom is youre a good candidate to continue AS. You could have a serious case that has just not yet been detected. But establishing a plan with your doc that includes all of these indicators will give you the ability to track changes over time and increase your chances of detecting a significant cancer before it is too late.

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsy results this is what my Urologist Recommended

Posts.Content: Over almost two years, I had two, 50 core biopsies that showed small Gleason 6 cancer in just three cores. Post-op it turned out to be Gleason 7 (3+4). Ill never know what a 12 core biopsy would have revealed, but I am glad I did the saturation biopsies and fortunate to have done the surgery when I did. My cancer was present in the nerves of the prostate. It is thought that traveling along the nerves is one of the ways it can spread. My doc also monitored PCA3. In the end, my decision to do robotic surgery was influenced in part by my high PCA3 numbers. A urine test measures the PCA3 gene which is prostate cancer specific. It is not influenced by the size of the prostate. During the DRE, the prostate is massaged (milked). Results depend upon the experience of the person doing the exam. So if you dont have an infection and you are thinking about Active Surveillance I would suggest you consider a plan that includes saturation biopsies, regular PSA tests, DREs, MRIs, Ultrasounds, and PCA3 tests. They are all different ways to gauge if cancer is present and how significant it can be. None of them is perfect. No one can predict the future with the degree of certainty we would like. Delaying treatment too long precludes some treatments and runs the risk that the disease will spread. Knowing when to stop AS and begin treatment can be tricky when the biopsy shows a small cancer and the conventional wisdom is youre a good candidate to continue AS. You could have a serious case that has just not yet been detected. But establishing a plan with your doc that includes all of these indicators will give you the ability to track changes over time and increase your chances of detecting a significant cancer before it is too late.

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsy results this is what my Urologist Recommended

Posts.Content: The saturation biopsies will cause inflammation and scar tissue. I had two, 50 core biopsies and surgeon said both inflammation and scar tissue were present when he did the surgery, but he spared nerves on both sides. My results are pretty good. This is where the experience, skill and success rates of the surgeon are really important. Patel is one of the best. Wishing you the best of luck.

Posts.Title: RALP after Saturation Biopsy

Posts.Content: When I was deciding to either have surgery or do another biopsie, my surgeon said that after two saturation biopsies, I already had a significant amount of scar tissue. Another biopsie might make the subsequent nerve sparing surgery more difficult. In the end I went ahead with the surgery. I had 100+ sample needles and it turned out that the scar tissue was not a problem. Bottom line; I wouldn't worry about scar tissue with the number of biopsies you have. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: My first biopsy was a saturation biopsy. My doc first wanted to do an MRI and followed up with the biopsy. Normal DRE so only an elevated PSA indicated something was going on. In my case I had two saturation biopsies with about 50 cores in each. Even with two, my Gleason 6 was upgraded to a 7 post surgery. Multiple saturation biopsies can miss serious cancers.

Posts.Title: Further action following testing for P.C

Posts.Content: Two years after robotic surgery life is getting better! Im still a zero, continent and with a little help from the blue pill, able to have a satisfying sex life. With the pill it is as good as it ever was. (No prior ED problems). On my own, without the pill, erections are serviceable but not as strong as before. My Doc says within the next year I might be able to give up the pill. Well see. I post this message to give hope to those who are coming after me. I also want to give a little advice. As many are coming to realize the Prostate Cancer game is one that is characterized by probabilities, luck, and skill. What are my chances that the cancer will be more serious than my biopsy indicates? With your biopsy Gleason score you can get a probability, based on the thousands of cases documented like yours, about the chances that your cancer is more serious. With a Gleason 6 you might have a 30% chance that your cancer is more severe. But at the same time you have a 70% chance that your 6 will stay a 6. Unfortunately there is currently no way to know which camp you fall into. So its a game of chance. You place your bet, and take your chances. Some opt for Active Surveillance while others seek treatment. If your 6 stays a 6 and you do AS, great. And if you opted for treatment under the same conditions you may kill the cancer but run the risk that you may suffer unwanted side effects. On the other hand, if your 6 is really a 7 or worse and you dont treat it, you will more likely than not see the disease progress and suffer its consequences. But if your 6 is really worse and you do treat it, then you may have just saved your life. Luck also plays a part in our game. Your cancer may be very aggressive, despite your relatively low PSA. It may have been detected early in its development or later when it is more advanced. You may or may not have a bad family history. Youve got what you got. Some of us are lucky while others are not. When it comes to treatment, the skill of your doctor is incredibly important. If I could offer only one piece of advice it would be that when it comes time to seek treatment, find the most skilled doctor you can find. Find the best even if you have to travel far to do so. Examine the chances your doctors patients have a recurrence, suffer with Ed, or have to deal with incontinence. Make sure to get their definitions of these conditions. In my case, I eventually opted for surgery. My doctors patients have a 97% chance of being continent after surgery (not needing any pads 6 months after surgery), a 15% chance of suffering with ED (not able to maintain an erection sufficient for intercourse 12 months after surgery), and a 95% chance of a cure. Do your homework and shop around. I got a second opinion on my slides, looked at radiation and seeds, consulted with an oncologist, a geneticist and a couple of other urologists. In the end no one else could beat these numbers. I think I'm making progress. Last year I posted this thread, one year after surgery. http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...c-Life-is-Good!

Posts.Content: Try to go as long as you can. I backed off when I came home and did 20 minute segments to get to at least an hour, but the gas stayed with me for 2 weeks or a little more. When I started to do the one hour straight the gas was gone in days. I pushed the day after surgery and was walking close to an hour in the hospital. Go easy, but keep moving.
